content.text: **Analogical reasoning** draws conclusions about one thing based on its similarity to another. If two things are alike in many respects, they're probably alike in other respects too.

content.definition: An argument that concludes something about a target case based on its similarity to a source case. If A and B are similar in respects 1, 2, 3, and A has property P, then B probably has P too.

content.title: Analogical Argument
premises: This drug worked on mice in clinical trials.
Mice are physiologically similar to humans in relevant respects.
content.conclusion: Therefore, the drug will probably work on humans.
content.note: The strength depends on how similar mice and humans are in the RELEVANT respects.

symbols.name: Pertinent Similarities
symbols.meaning: Shared properties must relate to the conclusion
symbols.example: Mice metabolism relevant to drug testing

symbols.name: Relevant Differences
symbols.example: Mice don't have human immune responses

symbols.name: Multiple Sources
symbols.meaning: More source cases strengthen the analogy
symbols.example: Drug worked on mice AND rats AND dogs

content.text: The key to strong analogies is **relevant similarity**. Two things might be similar in many ways but different in the way that matters. A toy car looks like a real car but can't transport people.

content.title: Weak Analogy
premises: The human body is like a machine.
Machines need regular maintenance to function.
content.note: The analogy breaks down. Bodies and machines differ in crucial ways.

content.question: What makes an analogical argument stronger?
options: More total similarities between the compared things
More RELEVANT similarities between the compared things
content.explanation: Analogical arguments are stronger when there are more RELEVANT similarities - similarities that bear on the property being inferred. Irrelevant similarities (both are blue, both were made on Tuesday) don't strengthen the argument at all.
